item.title: 39 Maharashtra Ministers Join Devendra Fadnavis' Cabinet. Full List - NDTV
item.description:
39 Maharashtra Ministers Join Devendra Fadnavis' Cabinet

Date: Today | Source: Maharashtra Government

The much-awaited cabinet expansion of the Maharashtra government led by Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis took place, with 39 ministers taking their oaths in Nagpur.

Key Points:

  • A total of 39 ministers were inducted into the cabinet.
  • 19 ministers from the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP).
  • 9 ministers from the Ajit Pawar-led Nationalist Congress Party (NCP).
  • 11 ministers from the Eknath Shinde-led Shiv Sena.

Full List of Ministers:

Bharatiya Janata Party: 19

  1. Chandrashekhar Bawankule
  2. Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil
  3. Chandrakant Patil
  4. Girish Mahajan
  5. Ganesh Naik
  6. Mangalprabhat Lodha
  7. Jaykumar Rawal
  8. Pankaja Munde
  9. Atul Save
  10. Ashok Uike
  11. Ashish Shelar
  12. Shivendra Raje Bhosale
  13. Jaykumar Gore
  14. Sanjay Sawakare
  15. Nitesh Rane
  16. Akash Fundkar
  17. Madhuri Misal (MoS)
  18. Dr. Pankaj Bhoyar (MoS)
  19. Meghana Bordikar Sakore (MoS)

Nationalist Congress Party: 9

  1. Hasan Mushrif
  2. Dhananjay Munde
  3. Dattatraya Bharne
  4. Aditi Tatkare
  5. Manikrao Kokate
  6. Narhari Zirwal
  7. Makrand Jadhav Patil
  8. Babasaheb Patil
  9. Indranil Naik (MoS)

Shiv Sena: 11

  1. Gulabrao Patil
  2. Dada Bhuse
  3. Sanjay Rathod
  4. Uday Samant
  5. Shambhuraje Desai
  6. Sanjay Shirsat
  7. Pratap Sarnaik
  8. Bharat Gogawale
  9. Prakash Abitkar
  10. Ashish Jaiswal (MoS)
  11. Yogesh Kadam (MoS)

item.title: Delhi Assembly Elections 2025: Game on with Kejriwal re-contesting; Congress drops candidates' list while Smriti Irani meets BJP veterans - Deccan Herald
item.description:
Delhi Assembly Elections 2025: Game on with Kejriwal re-contesting

Date: 15 December 2024

Source: Deccan Herald

The political arena heats up as Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal prepares to contest the upcoming Delhi Assembly elections for 2025, amidst speculations surrounding BJP candidates and Congress's decision to delay their candidates' list.

  • BJP has yet to announce any candidates for the elections.
  • Speculation about potential BJP candidates includes senior leaders like Smriti Irani and former MPs like Parvesh Verma and Ramesh Bidhuri.
  • Congress has not released their candidates' list, raising questions about their strategy.
No notable quotes available from the article.

As the election approaches, the dynamics among the political parties in Delhi will be crucial in determining the outcome.

item.title: ‘If you have problems with EVMs…': Omar Abdullah's salvo at INDIA ally Congress - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Omar Abdullah Critiques Congress on EVM Accountability

Date: Dec 15, 2024
Source: Hindustan Times

Jammu and Kashmir chief minister Omar Abdullah has criticized the Congress party for its inconsistent stance on Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs), suggesting that they cannot accept results they like and blame the EVMs for defeats.

  • Abdullah rebukes Congress for questioning EVMs after losing elections.
  • He argues that parties should be consistent in their trust of the voting mechanism.
  • Abdullah believes the Congress should have not relied solely on the National Conference during the recent campaign.
  • He emphasizes the need for clarity and principle in political discourse.
"When you get a hundred plus members of Parliament using the same EVMs... you can't then... say we don't like these EVMs because now the election results aren't going the way we would like them to." - Omar Abdullah

Abdullah emphasizes that electoral machines remain the same regardless of the outcomes and cautions against using them as excuses for electoral failure.

His remarks come amidst ongoing tensions between the National Conference and the Congress in the context of their alliance under the INDIA Bloc.

item.title: India must do more to tax its super rich, says Economist Thomas Piketty - Hindustan Times
item.description:
India must do more to tax its super rich, says Economist Thomas Piketty

Publication Date: Dec 15, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

French economist Thomas Piketty emphasized the need for India to implement higher taxes on its wealthiest individuals to combat rising inequality, proposing a 2% wealth tax and a 33% inheritance tax during a recent conference.

  • Piketty advocates for a 2% wealth tax on those with assets exceeding 100 million rupees ($1.18 million).
  • A 33% inheritance tax on properties valued at least 100 million rupees is suggested to ensure equitable distribution.
  • He argues these measures could generate revenue equivalent to 2.73% of India's GDP.
  • Piketty highlighted that 1% of Indians now control a disproportionate share of national income.
  • Current Indian government policies have favored wealth retention and growth without reintroducing wealth or inheritance taxes after their removal.
“India should be active in taxing the rich,” - Thomas Piketty

Despite support for wealth taxation from some economists, others, such as V. Anantha Nageswaran, caution against potential economic outflows that could result from increased taxation.
